title: How Does Storytelling Show Up at Work?
preview: As writers, it's easy to think that our storytelling skills don't matter as much in our day jobs, especially if we work for a large corporation.
body:
As writers, it's easy to think that our storytelling skills don’t matter as much in our day jobs, especially if we work for a large corporation. I have been guilty of thinking the sterile environment of an office doesn’t exactly lead to impressive creativity or much empathy.

However, the powers that be at Proctor & Gamble proved me wrong with their new advertising campaign for the world’s tiniest diaper.

The commercial, especially the scripted voice-over, left me on my couch in a puddle of tears.

It showed an extra small diaper created just for a micro-preemie. As a former NICU mom, I remember seeing babies whose tiny bodies couldn’t fit in the diapers.

My twins were born at 32 weeks in early 2021 as COVID ravaged the world and spent five and seven weeks in the NICU.

It is a unique and traumatic experience to have babies who need to spend a long stretch in the hospital before they can come home to their families.

In a short commercial, Pampers managed to show all the fear and hope that exists in the tiny fighters in the NICU and their families.

That’s the power of great storytelling within a company.

How are you using storytelling in your professional life today?
